instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_SO: What is PP3V3_SO? PP3V3_SO is a typo of PP3V3_S0.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board
threads.message:
Owner says the battery went flat, then they charged it and opened it up, but nothing comes up on screen. When switching in now, gives a good dong so you can tell it is switched on, knocking a few keys on the keyboard and it gives error sounds so it has loaded to at least the log on screen.
After diagnosis and testing, the story so far from moving backwards from the lcd connecter: [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Need to see if voltage is getting to the screen[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]It knows when the screen has been closed as it goes to sleep when you close it[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]The screen does not come back on when you open it, but it does wake up[/FONT][/COLOR] [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is the screen/graphics being told to switch on?[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is there <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> there? At pins 2 and 3 of lcd connector?[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is at pin 3[/FONT][/COLOR] [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is the voltage there for the backlight at pins 38 39 40? [/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]0.02v is there[/FONT][/COLOR] [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is there <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SO</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R9010</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R9011</RESISTOR> <CAPACITOR>C9010</CAPACITOR>[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Yes it is, the components test all ok[/FONT][/COLOR] [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is there <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL> at:[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]l9000 no[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]<CAPACITOR>C9001</CAPACITOR> no[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]<CAPACITOR>C9002</CAPACITOR> no[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]<CAPACITOR>C9011</CAPACITOR> no[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]<CAPACITOR>C9012</CAPACITOR> no[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Components test ok though[/FONT][/COLOR] [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]<CHIP>U9000</CHIP>[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is there 3v3 at pin 2 3 4 5[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Voltages only at pin 2 and 3 so <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is working[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Pin 4 and 5 are output[/FONT][/COLOR] [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is there <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at pin 1 or 2 of <CAPACITOR>C9009</CAPACITOR>[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Correct voltage is at pin 1[/FONT][/COLOR] [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Is <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R9094</RESISTOR>[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]No voltage at that component[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Need to find source of <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]Comes from <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>[/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]<CHIP>U9701</CHIP> (lp 8550) looks like it might be burnt out, this is for the led backlight

So up to now it looks like it has a backlight AND graphics problem, I haven't done any testing for backlight yet other than seeing that <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> is burnt out

Can <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> be reflowed/reballed or will it need replacing?

The device isn't liquid damaged, I can't quiye believe the issue it has would come from the battery going flat, but there you go.
So I am just wondering what to do about <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> to at least get the graphics back then tackle the backlight.

Thanks for reading.[/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board
threads.message: What area was liquid damaged? Is there video on external screen?

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board
threads.message: It isn't liquid damaged at all, sorry, read my previous post and corrected it, no adapter at the moment. I will get an adapter and update again.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board
threads.message: I would say this would qualify for the Apple recall program then. Take it to Apple.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board
threads.message: What programme is that? Is it on their website?

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board
threads.message: Just found it. I'd like to give the repair a go, but with the risks involved, I had best bow out instead.

threads.title: Macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board
threads.message: Just as an update to this, it has gone to Apple. Connecting an external display didn't give any change.
